content: hi it's Lucas from barge crafts this week I made some flowers for my simple
tabletop castles besides using these for my castle terrain they can be used as
normal tiles for your taverns let's begin
if you appreciate the content press that like to let me know and subscribe to the
channel for more I started by cutting a thin sheet of foam for the planks then I
took some measurements from the modular castle pieces it seems like the foam
piece is double the length of a plan good then I cut out thin strips
intentionally and unintentionally I made lines of different thickness this
will make the floor tiles look less even older and just better
for the next step we'll be using card
stock I eat instant oats because I'm always in
a hurry I measured and cut out pieces that fits right into the castle rooms
yeah that's perfect now I can just cut the planks into suitable length and
attach them to the cart by fully covering the cardstock with PVA glue the
foam planks will stick will and the floor tiles will be durable and have a
bit of weight when gluing on the planks keep this in mind what makes the floor
tiles look better are the gaps between the planks the large uneven gaps will
add a lot of contrast once the floors are painted and they will emphasize the
fact that these floors are made from individual planks the glue has dried I
expected the floors to warp but they didn't here learn some Finnish
and Swedish now that the glue has dried a bit I can trim the planks into the
right length let's not forget the doors to give space to the modular doors we
must cut away a bit of the card stock and then attach the plank accordingly
I met smaller floors for the remaining
rooms before the glue dries you can still adjust the position of the planks
make sure that the gaps are good and don't worry about planks that look too
long you can just trim them off later I realized it's easier to make space for
the door by cutting away material after you have attached the planks on a
complete piece
all right it seems to fit before moving on I met Flores for the rest of the
rooms in my castle keep after this video you can go check out the rest of my
castle trail straightforward and easy to make now it's time to make some good
textures you can carve random wavy lines with a pencil
well then use a steel wire brush now you just enjoy the sounds
over the few years of crafting I have
experienced I have learned that steel wire wood textures have smaller details
that also look good in close-up camera shots textures made with the pen have
enough detail for the human eye but when taking close-ups with the camera
the textures seem lacking at least this is my experience alright that looks
really good though and now it's time to paint
and after that we'll figure out a way how to feed these into the different
levels of the castle key and how to make them stay in place as you can see I base
coated the entire piece with black also the bottom once done with the base coat
I painted with a golden brown color I mixed a bit of yellow into the brown
acrylic paint I have I applied half coverage and did my best to avoid
painting in the cracks and gaps of the planks the brown looks a bit bright
while painting however when the paint dries it will be significantly darker
due to the black base coat all right don't forget the edges and you can leave
the bottom of the piece black after drying a bit I added more paint to areas
that I thought were too dark now I will let them dry completely and then we'll
make some scientific tests to see if the tiles are durable good they seem to be
toddler proof now I'll dry brush the tiles with a tan
this is by far the simplest way of painting good looking planks I have
encountered to make this all look better you could add nails and then use
different lengths of lines I didn't think of this earlier but now you know
okay the bottom floor is fine and it works
but when we add the next floor we will encounter a problem
naturally the solution is too thick let's cut this toothpicks into shorter
pieces and see what we can do I'll just take the room and figure out
the right position to stick in the toothpicks at about this height the
floor should be able to rest on the toothpicks exactly at the level of the
stone walls take some glue and stick into sticks in the two opposing inner
walls I then did the rest of the pieces and I'm excited to see how it works
but first I'll just paint the sticks with black if you want to you can paint
some rust or metallic effects on the sticks but for me just black is fine all
right now we can start assembling the castle I have already used these pieces
in a D&D session together with the frost crystals from the last episode you know
what I'll show you the most amazing snow terrain you can get in a shot from my
last game you'll love it ah wood and stone the perfect
combination I want to live in a castle here you can see how this can work well
as regular floor tiles the large gaps between the planks are really what makes
these look great before you see the ultimate snow terrain
tell me did you like the castle floors and if you're new to bards craft join
the party and subscribe for more terrain and miniatures okay here it comes
this is literally the best piece of terrain I've ever had a white towel next
week on barge craft searching for terrain in the depths of Ikea join the
path of tabletop crafting if you truly appreciate the work go check out Bart's
craft on patreon support original art in return you get stuff you really don't
need with the support we can do amazing things right now I'm searching for
better components for my CD editing computer I wouldn't be comfortable
investing without the help of my patrons and occasional PayPal donations I don't
even play video games anymore thank you your support means more to me than you
might think I'm really grateful I hope you enjoyed this episode more next week
I wish you a big crafting moment goodbye
you
